body:
For changes like this, it's important to explain the goal in the PR description. All things being equal, immutable classes are better than mutable ones. However, the Controller is a delicate area and we don't have great test coverage (we want to improve this). As such, it would be good to explain the motivation.

@guozhangwang, the performance tests that run nightly are a bit simplistic and I don't think the controller is the bottleneck in any of them. So, not sure if running them will achieve the desired goal here.

cc @ijuma @junrao @apurvam 

One of the nice benefits of the new message format is the ability to do streaming decompression of fetched data. In the old message format, we had to decompress each record batch in full before returning any data because we needed to find the last offset to determine the initial offset. But in the new format, we have everything we need in the batch header, so we can return records to the user as they are being decompressed. This works nicely with the consumer's `max.poll.records` config. We only decompress and deserialize as much data as we need to satisfy each `poll()` and we can leave the rest compressed. The benefit is reduced memory utilization (see also KIP-81).

Would it be a good idea to change the default number of partitions for the offsets topic in `TestUtils.createBrokerConfig`? That should make the integrations test suite faster, right?

Also, do we think this has started happening more frequently recently and, if so, do we have any theory why?

A few more things I noticed:
1. A few tests don't shutdown the `executor`. Maybe worth fixing that as part of this PR.
2. It looks like a number of tests in that class use mocks and are unit tests. Could we separate the integration and unit tests so that we avoid the expensive Kafka setup/teardown for the unit tests?
3. `IntegrationTestHarness` creates the offsets topic (`TestUtils.createOffsetsTopic(zkUtils, servers`) during setup instead of relying on auto creation. That tends to be more robust and we could add that line to the setup of this test too perhaps (since it doesn't inherit from `IntegrationTestHarness`).

@mjsax can you please check?

Thanks for comments @guozhangwang, @ijuma. Reason for this change is that Scala case classes should be always defined as immutable, because they provide some "mutable not friendly" stuff, like automatic generation of equals and hashCode methods. I am sure you would agree that having mutable case class prevent us using this class as key in the map. Which cannot be forced by compiler. Having case class immutable prevents this and it is considered good practice.
